snippet: Temperatures fell into the 30s on Sunday and are expected to drop below freezing this week as tens of thousands of people search for someplace to live.
abstract: New York City officials say that they face the daunting challenge of finding homes for as many as 40,000 people who were left homeless after the devastation of Hurricane Sandy; Mayor Michael R Bloomberg says that figure, from Housing and Urban Development agency, is a worst case scenario and that a more realistic assessment is 20,000, mostly residents of public housing; he emphasizes that either scenario is daunting.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Michael M. Grynbaum, Mary Pilon, Eric Lipton, Steve Eder, Vivian Yee, Patrick McGeehan and Thomas Kaplan.

lead_paragraph: Temperatures fell into the 30s on Sunday and are expected to drop below freezing this week as tens of thousands of people search for someplace to live.

headline.main: Housing Nightmare Looms in Wake of Storm
headline.print_headline: Housing Nightmare Looms in Wake of Storm
